FREMONT, Ohio, Nov. 9, 2020 – ProMedica Health System announced today that ProMedica Memorial Hospital is 5-star rated for outcomes in the specialty areas of pulmonary, gastrointestinal and critical care, according to new research released by Healthgrades, the leading resource that connects consumers, physicians and health systems. Every year, Healthgrades evaluates hospital performance at nearly 4,500 hospitals nationwide for 32 of the most common inpatient procedures and conditions using Medicare data, and additional analyzes outcomes in appendectomy and bariatric surgery using all-payer data provided by 16 states.

This analysis shows that patients treated at hospitals receiving a 5-star rating have a lower risk of dying and a lower risk of experiencing one or more complications during a hospital stay than if they were treated at hospitals receiving a 1-star rating in that procedure or condition. From 2017 through 2019, if all hospitals as a group performed similarly to hospitals receiving 5-stars as a group, on average, 218,785 lives could potentially have been saved and complications in 148,681 patients could potentially have been avoided.*
 
Additionally, Healthgrades assesses outcomes in elective care and the relative performance of 5-star hospitals vs 1- and 3-star hospitals and how this may affect patients. For example, ProMedica Memorial Hospital was recognized as a 5-star hospital for treatment of heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease for two consecutive years. According to Healthgrades, this means patients treated at ProMedica Memorial Hospital have a 60.5% and 83.3% lower chance of dying when treated for those conditions, than patients treated at a 1-star rated facility.

“Hospital quality has never been more important, and consumers are becoming more aware of the importance of researching where they receive care before they visit a hospital for a specific procedure or condition,” said Brad Bowman, MD, Chief Medical Officer at Healthgrades. “Hospitals that receive a Healthgrades 5-star rating for specialty service lines demonstrate exceptional outcomes and their ability to provide quality care for patients.”

“Being a Healthgrades 5-Star Recipient in multiple specialties, for consecutive years in most cases, is a testament to the dedication of our physicians and care teams who strive to deliver the best clinical care to the Fremont area,” says Deana Sievert, president of ProMedica Memorial Hospital. “We hope this well-respected recognition helps to reassure patients that we are fully committed to implementing best practices that help to ensure the best health care outcomes.”

ProMedica Memorial Hospital also received the following recognition from Healthgrades for superior clinical care achievements:

  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Heart Failure for 2 Years in a Row (2020-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease for 2 Years in a Row (2020-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Bowel Obstruction for 2 Years in a Row (2020-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Respiratory Failure for 2 Years in a Row (2020-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Hip Fracture Treatment in 2021

For its analysis, Healthgrades evaluated approximately 45 million Medicare inpatient records for nearly 4,500 short-term acute care hospitals nationwide to assess hospital performance in 32 common conditions and procedures, and evaluated outcomes in appendectomy and bariatric surgery using all-payer data provided by 16 states. Healthgrades recognizes a hospital’s quality achievements for cohort-specific performance, specialty area performance, and overall clinical quality. Individual procedure or condition cohorts are designated as 5-star (statistically significantly better than expected), 3-star (not statistically different from expected) and 1-star (statistically significantly worse than expected). View the full list of Specialty Excellence AwardTM recipients here. The complete Healthgrades 2021 Report to the Nation and detailed study methodology, can be found at https://partners.healthgrades.com/healthgrades-quality-solutions/healthgrades-quality-awards/.

*Statistics are based on Healthgrades analysis of MedPAR data for years 2017 through 2019 and represent three-year estimates for Medicare patients only. For appendectomy and bariatric surgery, Healthgrades used inpatient data from 16 states that provide all-payer data for years 2016 through 2018.

name: ProMedica Toledo Hospital Named One of Americas Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery and Cardiac Care Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Toledo Hospital Named One of America's Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery and Cardiac Care Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Toledo Hospital Named One of America's Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery and Cardiac Care

Press Release
ProMedica Toledo Hospital Named One of America's Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery and Cardiac Care

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 6, 2020 – ProMedica, a mission-based, not-for-profit health and well-being organization, announced that ProMedica Toledo Hospital is ranked among America’s 50 Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery, according to recent research released by Healthgrades, the leading resource that connects consumers, physicians and health systems. The hospital also ranked among America's 100 Best Hospitals for Cardiac Care for the ninth year in a row. Each year, Healthgrades evaluates hospital performance at nearly 4,500 hospitals nationwide for 32 of the most common inpatient procedures and conditions using Medicare data, and all-payer data from 16 states for bariatrics and appendectomy procedures.*

According to Healthgrades, the hospitals that have achieved the Healthgrades America’s Best Hospitals recognition for specialty service lines have demonstrated exceptional quality of care. For example, Healthgrades compared America’s 50 Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery Award recipients as a group, to all other hospitals, as a group, and found that from 2017-2019, patients treated at hospitals receiving the America’s 50 Best Hospitals for Cardiac Surgery Award have, on average, 54.4 percent lower risk of dying than if they were treated in hospitals that did not receive the award.

“Now more than ever, consumers understand the importance of hospital quality and starting to become more diligent when researching where they receive care,” said Brad Bowman, MD, Chief Medical Officer, Healthgrades. “When selecting a hospital, consumers can feel confident in the America’s 50/100 Best Hospitals for specialty service lines for their commitment to quality care and exceptional outcomes.”

ProMedica Toledo Hospital also received the following recognition from Healthgrades for superior clinical care achievements:

  • One of Healthgrades America's 100 Best Hospitals for Joint Replacement™ for 6 Years in a Row (2016-2021)
  • One of Healthgrades America's 100 Best Hospitals for Pulmonary Care™ for 7 Years in a Row (2015-2021)
  • One of Healthgrades America's 100 Best Hospitals for Gastrointestinal Care™ for 8 Years in a Row (2014-2021)
  • One of Healthgrades America's 100 Best Hospitals for General Surgery™ for 3 Years in a Row (2019-2021)
  • Critical Care Excellence Award™ (2021)
  • Stroke Care Excellence Award™ (2021, 2019)

“We are thrilled to be recognized among the very best in the nation for numerous specialty services we provide at ProMedica Toledo Hospital,” said Dawn Buskey, ProMedica president of acute care. “As the only hospital cardiac program in the Toledo area to receive the America’s 50 Best Hospitals specialty designation, we hope our community members feel more confident than ever that they can stay close to home and still access the expertise that drives the best clinical outcomes.”

Buskey added, “The Healthgrades’ recognition wouldn’t have been possible without continuous dedication from our highly trained physicians and healthcare teams. Even with the challenges presented by the pandemic this year, they have demonstrated an unwavering commitment to delivering the highest quality care to our patients.”

For its analysis, Healthgrades evaluated approximately 45 million Medicare inpatient records for nearly 4,500 short-term acute care hospitals nationwide to assess hospital performance in 32 common conditions and procedures, and evaluated outcomes in appendectomy and bariatric surgery using all-payer data provided by 16 states. Healthgrades recognizes a hospital’s quality achievements for cohort-specific performance, specialty area performance, and overall clinical quality. Individual procedure or condition cohorts are designated as 5-star (statistically significantly better than expected), 3-star (not statistically different from expected) and 1-star (statistically significantly worse than expected). View the full list of Specialty Excellence AwardTM recipients here. The complete Healthgrades 2021 Report to the Nation and detailed study methodology, can be found at https://partners.healthgrades.com/healthgrades-quality-solutions/healthgrades-quality-awards/

* Statistics are based on Healthgrades analysis of MedPAR data for years 2017 through 2019 and represent three-year estimates for Medicare patients only. For appendectomy and bariatric surgery, Healthgrades used inpatient data from 16 states that provide all-payer data for years 2016 through 2018.

name: ProMedica Bixby Hospital Now ProMedica Hickman Hospital is Healthgrades Fivestar Recipient for Pulmonary Gastrointestinal and Critical Care Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Bixby Hospital (Now ProMedica Hickman Hospital) is Healthgrades Five-star Recipient for Pulmonary Gastrointestinal and Critical Care Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Bixby Hospital (Now ProMedica Hickman Hospital) is Healthgrades Five-star Recipient for Pulmonary Gastrointestinal and

Press Release
ProMedica Bixby Hospital (Now ProMedica Hickman Hospital) is Healthgrades Five-star Recipient for Pulmonary Gastrointestinal and Critical Care

ADRIAN, MI, Nov. 6, 2020 – ProMedica Health System announced today that ProMedica Bixby Hospital (now part of ProMedica Charles and Virginia Hickman Hospital) received a 5-star rating for outcomes in the specialty areas of pulmonary, gastrointestinal and critical care, according to new research released by Healthgrades, the leading resource that connects consumers, physicians and health systems. Every year, Healthgrades evaluates hospital performance at nearly 4,500 hospitals nationwide for 32 of the most common inpatient procedures and conditions using Medicare data, and additional analyzes outcomes in appendectomy and bariatric surgery using all-payer data provided by 16 states. The hospital was recognized under its previous name since its transition into ProMedica Hickman Hospital did not happen until late September 2020.

This analysis shows that patients treated at hospitals receiving a 5-star rating have a lower risk of dying and a lower risk of experiencing one or more complications during a hospital stay than if they were treated at hospitals receiving a 1-star rating in that procedure or condition. From 2017 through 2019, if all hospitals as a group performed similarly to hospitals receiving 5-stars as a group, on average, 218,785 lives could potentially have been saved and complications in 148,681 patients could potentially have been avoided.

Additionally, Healthgrades assesses outcomes in elective care and the relative performance of 5-star hospitals vs 1- and 3-star hospitals and how this may affect patients. During the assessment, Healthgrades was able to discover patients treated for respiratory failure at 1-star rated facilities were 2.0 times more likely to die than patients treated at 5-star facilities, which is one specialty area ProMedica Bixby Hospital was recognized as a 5-Star Recipient for four consecutive years.

“Hospital quality has never been more important, and consumers are becoming more aware of the importance of researching where they receive care before they visit a hospital for a specific procedure or condition,” said Brad Bowman, MD, Chief Medical Officer at Healthgrades. “Hospitals that receive a Healthgrades 5-star rating for specialty service lines demonstrate exceptional outcomes and their ability to provide quality care for patients.”

“Being recognized as a 5-star hospital in several different specialty areas is truly the best way to end ProMedica Bixby Hospital’s legacy as our team transitioned to a new facility,” said Julie Yaroch, DO, president of ProMedica Charles and Virginia Hickman Hospital. “We are excited to be recognized for our superior clinical outcomes and to now be able to deliver the same high quality care to the Adrian community at the new ProMedica Charles and Virginia Hickman Hospital.”

ProMedica Bixby Hospital also received the following recognition from Healthgrades for superior clinical care achievements:

  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Respiratory Failure for 4 Years in a Row (2018-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Colorectal Surgeries for 3 Years in a Row (2019-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Bowel Obstruction for 3 Years in a Row (2019-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Sepsis for 2 Years in a Row (2020-2021)
  • Five-Star Recipient for Treatment of Pneumonia (2021)

For its analysis, Healthgrades evaluated approximately 45 million Medicare inpatient records for nearly 4,500 short-term acute care hospitals nationwide to assess hospital performance in 32 common conditions and procedures, and evaluated outcomes in appendectomy and bariatric surgery using all-payer data provided by 16 states. Healthgrades recognizes a hospital’s quality achievements for cohort-specific performance, specialty area performance, and overall clinical quality. Individual procedure or condition cohorts are designated as 5-star (statistically significantly better than expected), 3-star (not statistically different from expected) and 1-star (statistically significantly worse than expected). View the full list of Specialty Excellence AwardTM recipients here. The complete Healthgrades 2021 Report to the Nation and detailed study methodology, can be found at https://partners.healthgrades.com/healthgrades-quality-solutions/healthgrades-quality-awards/.

*Statistics are based on Healthgrades analysis of MedPAR data for years 2017 through 2019 and represent three-year estimates for Medicare patients only. For appendectomy and bariatric surgery, Healthgrades used inpatient data from 16 states that provide all-payer data for years 2016 through 2018.

name: ProMedica Announces HCR ManorCare Name Change and Rebrand Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Announces HCR ManorCare Name Change and Rebrand Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Announces HCR ManorCare Name Change and Rebrand

Press Release
ProMedica Announces HCR ManorCare Name Change and Rebrand

TOLEDO, Ohio, October 2, 2020 – ProMedica, a mission-based, not-for-profit health and well-being organization, today announced that its division, HCR ManorCare, has been renamed ProMedica Senior Care. The rebrand is part of an evolving journey to unite two organizations, which began with ProMedica’s acquisition of HCR ManorCare in 2018.

Today, ProMedica is comprised of three distinct, but aligned care divisions: Senior Care, Provider and Clinical Services, and Paramount Health Plan.

ProMedica’s rebrand supports the organization’s efforts to intentionally bring together diverse health and well-being services to help individuals reach their highest potential for health. This diversity allows ProMedica to champion healthy aging, cultivate innovative solutions and lead in the area of social determinants of health.

The rebrand reflects how ProMedica is redefining the delivery of health care to go beyond the walls of a hospital, exam room, senior care facility or office. It also underscores the organization’s focus on caring for the whole person, including health and well-being.

Over the next 18 months, facility names and physical sign changes will be rolled out at ProMedica Senior Care facilities across the nation. The brands that will be changing include Heartland, ManorCare and Arden Courts.

name: ProMedica Researchers first in US to enroll patients in International COVID19 clinical research study Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Researchers first in U.S. to enroll patients in International COVID-19 clinical research study Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Researchers first in U.S. to enroll patients in International COVID-19 clinical research study

Press Release
ProMedica Researchers first in U.S. to enroll patients in International COVID-19 clinical research study

TOLEDO, Ohio, September 14, 2020 – ProMedica today announced that it enrolled the first two patients in the United States in a global clinical trial to evaluate an oral medication for treatment of patients with COVID-19. The study, “A Randomized Open Label Phase 2b/3 Study of the Safety and Efficacy of NP-120 (Ifenprodil) for the Treatment of Hospitalized Patients with Confirmed COVID-19 Disease”, is investigating the safety and efficacy of Ifenprodil on lung function, health status and SARS-CoV-2 RNA status in hospitalized patients with COVID-19 disease. The study is sponsored by Algernon Pharmaceuticals located in Vancouver British Columbia, Canada.

Ifenprodil, an NMDA antagonist, may be useful in preventing virus-induced acute lung injury. In vitro studies suggest Ifenprodil may block the activation of T cells and cytokine release, and therefore, could be a potent anti-inflammatory agent.

According to the Principal Investigator, ProMedica Critical Care physician, Marla Matal, MD “Our hope is to prevent patients from getting intubated and suffering through the mental and physical agony of a prolonged ICU stay.”

Other ProMedica study team members include Sub-investigator, Greg Kasper, MD, Clinical Research Coordinators, Jessica Shoemaker, RN, and Bailea Bobich, RN and pharmacists Beth Martin, Elice Martin and David Chen.

The study is currently screening and enrolling at ProMedica Toledo Hospital and ProMedica Bay Park Hospital. For more details about the study, please visit the study record on ClinicalTrials.gov.

name: ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns American College of Radiology Accreditation in Nuclear Medicine Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns American College of Radiology Accreditation in Nuclear Medicine Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns American College of Radiology Accreditation in Nuclear Medicine

Press Release
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns American College of Radiology Accreditation in Nuclear Medicine

FOSTORIA, Ohio, September 9, 2020 – ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital has been awarded a three-year term of accreditation in nuclear medicine as the result of a recent review by the American College of Radiology (ACR). Nuclear medicine is a branch of medical imaging that uses small amounts of radioactive material to diagnose and treat a variety of diseases, including many types of cancers, heart disease and certain other abnormalities within the body.

“Earning the ACR accreditation in nuclear medicine is one way Fostoria Community Hospital strives to provide safe, high-quality radiology and imaging services to the community,” said Nathan Egbert, MD, medical director of radiology at Fostoria Community Hospital.

The ACR gold seal of accreditation represents the highest level of image quality and patient safety. It is awarded only to facilities meeting ACR Practice Parameters and Technical Standards after a peer-review evaluation by board-certified physicians and medical physicists who are experts in the field. Image quality, personnel qualifications, adequacy of facility equipment, quality control procedures and quality assurance programs are assessed. The findings are reported to the ACR Committee on Accreditation, which subsequently provides the practice with a comprehensive report that can be used for continuous practice improvement.

The ACR, founded in 1924, is a professional medical society dedicated to serving patients and society by empowering radiology professionals to advance the practice, science and professions of radiological care. The College serves more than 37,000 diagnostic/interventional radiologists, radiation oncologists, nuclear medicine physicians, and medical physicists with programs focusing on the practice of medical imaging and radiation oncology and the delivery of comprehensive health care services.

name: ProMedica Toledo Hospital Among Nations Top Performing Hospitals for Treatment of Heart Attack Patients Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Toledo Hospital Among Nation's Top Performing Hospitals for Treatment of Heart Attack Patients Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Toledo Hospital Among Nation's Top Performing Hospitals for Treatment of Heart Attack Patients

Press Release
ProMedica Toledo Hospital Among Nation's Top Performing Hospitals for Treatment of Heart Attack Patients

TOLEDO, August 27, 2020 – ProMedica Toledo Hospital has received the American College of Cardiology’s NCDR Chest Pain-Myocardial Infarction (MI) Registry Silver Performance Achievement Award for 2020. ProMedica Toledo Hospital is one of only 124 hospitals nationwide to receive the honor.

The award recognizes ProMedica Toledo Hospital’s commitment and success in implementing a higher standard of care for heart attack patients and signifies that ProMedica Toledo Hospital has reached an aggressive goal of treating these patients to standard levels of care as outlined by the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association clinical guidelines and recommendations. Specifically, these three areas contributed to the award: the Emergency Department, CardioVascular Services, and the ProMedica Toledo Hospital Cardiac Nursing Units.

To receive the Chest Pain - MI Registry Silver Performance Achievement Award, ProMedica Toledo Hospital has demonstrated sustained achievement in the Chest Pain - MI Registry for four consecutive quarters during 2019 and performed with distinction in specific performance measures. Full participation in the registry engages hospitals in a robust quality improvement process using data to drive improvements in adherence to guideline recommendations and overall quality of care provided to heart attack patients.

“As a Silver Performance Award recipient, ProMedica Toledo Hospital has established itself as a leader in setting the national standard for improving quality of care in patients with acute myocardial infarction,” said Michael C. Kontos, MD, FACC, chair of the NCDR Chest Pain-MI Registry Steering Subcommittee, Virginia Commonwealth University Medical Center. “By meeting the award requirements set forth in the registry, ProMedica Toledo Hospital has demonstrated a commitment to providing reliable, comprehensive treatment for heart attack patients based on current clinical guideline recommendations.”

The Center for Disease Control estimates that almost 700,000 Americans suffer a heart attack each year. A heart attack occurs when a blood clot in a coronary artery partially or completely blocks blood flow to the heart muscle. Treatment guidelines include administering aspirin upon arrival and discharge, timely restoration of blood flow to the blocked artery, smoking cessation counseling and cardiac rehabilitation, among others.

“It is an honor to be recognized by the American College of Cardiology for our continued commitment to service and quality for our patients and their families,” said Rajendra Kattar, MD, FACC, president, ProMedica Heart Institute. “As an organization, we strive every day to find ways to improve our processes and outcomes in ways that benefit our patients.”

Chest Pain - MI Registry empowers health care provider teams to consistently treat heart attack patients according to the most current, science-based guidelines and establishes a national standard for understanding and improving the quality, safety and outcomes of care provided for patients with coronary artery disease, specifically high-risk heart attack patients.

For more information about ProMedica cardiology, including 24/7 care, please visit promedica.org.

name: ProMedica Farms Awarded a Michigan Health Endowment Fund Grant Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Farms Awarded a Michigan Health Endowment Fund Grant Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Farms Awarded a Michigan Health Endowment Fund Grant

Press Release
ProMedica Farms Awarded a Michigan Health Endowment Fund Grant

TECUMSEH, MI, August 21, 2020 – The Michigan Health Endowment Fund awarded a grant for more than $400,000 to ProMedica Farms, ProMedica announced today. This two-year grant will support and expand the work started in 2017 on the farm by providing a new living laboratory for youth, seniors, and families; a therapeutic healing space for patients and staff of ProMedica Charles and Virginia Hickman Hospital; and fresh, locally grown food to members of the Lenawee community.

“Aligned with our vision to create communities where all individuals reach their highest potential for health, this project will use ProMedica Farms as a central hub to support initiatives that address the Social Determinants of Health within Lenawee County, such as access to food and education,” says Frank Nagle, manager of population health and community relations, ProMedica.

ProMedica Farms on the campus of ProMedica Charles and Virginia Hickman Hospital is available for everyone to access fresh fruits and vegetables, as well as opportunities for education and therapy. ProMedica Farms includes a farmhouse for community meetings and workshops, a historical barn for farmers’ markets, and a clinical hoop house. Additionally, the farm features a 1,800 square foot garage that is converted into a health and nutrition learning center.

“We are grateful for the Michigan Health Endowment Fund grant opportunity. This grant will go a long way in supporting community collaborations that increase access to affordable fresh produce, evidence-based educational opportunities, and gardening workshops,” says Julie Yaroch, DO, President, ProMedica Bixby and Herrick Hospitals. “We will be well equipped to direct patients and residents to resources that address their specific health needs.”

For more information, please contact ProMedica.Farms@ProMedica.org.

name: ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns 5Star Rating in Patient Experience by CMS Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns 5-Star Rating in Patient Experience by CMS Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns 5-Star Rating in Patient Experience by CMS

Press Release
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Earns 5-Star Rating in Patient Experience by CMS

FOSTORIA, Ohio, August 19, 2020 – ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital is pleased to have earned a 5-star rating in patient experience by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services’ (CMS) Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (HCAHPS) summary star ratings.

CMS' summary star rating scores hospitals on a one-to-five-star scale based on the 10 publicly reported measures in the HCAHPS survey, which assesses patient experiences. The agency started assigning hospital patient experience star ratings based solely on HCAHPS scores in April 2015. The latest update is based on HCAHPS survey data collected between Jan. 1, 2019, and Dec. 31, 2019.

“As a community hospital, we feel it’s so important that patients have the best experience possible while in our care,” says Pam Jensen, president, ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital. “When a patient comes through our doors, they trust us to bring them the most caring, dedicated clinical expertise possible. We’re proud to serve the community knowing patient experience is one of our top priorities.”

Fostoria Community Hospital was one of only 266 out of 3,478 hospitals in the United States (as of July 31) to have earned five stars in patient experience by CMS.

name: ProMedica Toledo Hospital Receives 15 M Grant from Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Toledo Hospital Receives $1.5 M Grant from Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Toledo Hospital Receives $1.5 M Grant from Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

Press Release
ProMedica Toledo Hospital Receives $1.5 M Grant from Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 13, 2020 – ProMedica Toledo Hospital announced today that over the course of three years, it will receive a $1.5 million grant from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMSHA) to assist in the implementation of ProMedica’s Prescribing Alternatives Instead of Narcotics (PAIN) project throughout Lucas County.

The PAIN project will work to offer alternatives to opioids to those who present with common pain conditions at ProMedica Toledo Hospital and ProMedica Flower Hospital Emergency Departments. The targeted pain conditions that will be a point of focus at both facilities include:

  • Headache/migraine
  • Extremity fracture/sprain
  • Low back pain
  • Dental pain
  • Renal colic (pain associated with kidney stone)

To supplement the non-opioid medication alternatives, non-pharmacological pain reduction interventions will be used as enhanced pain-alleviating strategies. The grant from SAMHSA will allow the emergency departments to increase their use of non-pharmacological alternatives by 20 percent or more. These interventions include physical therapy, acupuncture, and cognitive behavioral therapy among others.

The PAIN project’s goal is to decrease the number of opioids prescribed to patients presenting with acute pain-related conditions at ProMedica Toledo Hosptial and ProMedica Flower Hospital Emergency Departments by 45 percent, or more, over the next three years.

“We look forward to having the opportunity to further provide the best quality of care to our patients,” said Brian Kaminski, DO, ProMedica vice president of quality and safety. “With the increased need to address the number of opioids prescribed to patients, this grant should allow us to provide these specific services to approximately 8,000 individuals over the next three years.”

By August 31, 2023, the PAIN project will offer medication-assisted treatment and subsequent referral for ongoing treatment to 90 percent of patients who present to ProMedica Toledo Hospital and ProMedica Flower Hospital Emergency Departments with a substance use disorder.

This project will enhance existing efforts at ProMedica Toledo Hosptial and ProMedica Flower Hospital Emergency Departments to address the growing number of opioid overdoses treated at each facility and reduce the number of patients with opiate use disorder.

name: ProMedica Partners with LPGA Drive On Championship to Raise Awareness of the Social Determinants of Health Nonprofit Organizatio Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Partners with LPGA Drive On Championship to Raise Awareness of the Social Determinants of Health Nonprofit Organizatio Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Partners with LPGA Drive On Championship to Raise Awareness of the Social Determinants of Health Nonprofit Organizatio

Press Release
ProMedica Partners with LPGA Drive On Championship to Raise Awareness of the Social Determinants of Health Nonprofit Organizatio

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 30, 2020 – ProMedica, a mission-based, not-for-profit health and well-being organization, today announced that it has teamed up with the LPGA Drive On Championship to raise national awareness of the social determinants of health (SDOH) and the impact they have on health outcomes.

The LPGA Drive On Championship will take place in Toledo, Ohio at the Inverness Club July 31 – August 2. The event will be televised on the Golf Channel nationwide all three days. During the event, ProMedica will air several nationally-televised messages aimed at explaining:

  • The social determinants of health
  • How they affect health outcomes
  • The disparities associated with them

The social determinants of health are the social, economic, and environmental factors that impact health risks and outcomes. They include factors such as food insecurity, financial strain, housing, behavioral health, transportation, violence risks, and childcare. While these needs already have been critical in many communities, they are now being intensified by the COVID-19 pandemic.

ProMedica has long served as a national leader in addressing the social determinants of health. To help further awareness about the cause, the organization has designated August as Social Determinants of Health Awareness Month.

The partnership with the LPGA Drive On Championship provides a major opportunity to bolster national awareness of SDOH leading into August. During the event, LPGA players are expected to show their support for social determinants of health awareness by wearing green ribbons.

“We’re pleased to be partnering with the LPGA to raise awareness for a cause as important as the social determinants of health,” said Randy Oostra, president and CEO of ProMedica. “The need for awareness and intervention is greater than ever before, especially in light of the pandemic. ProMedica has been committed to advancing SDOH initiatives for more than a decade, and we are always excited to form new partnerships that enable us to further our efforts.”

Moving beyond awareness to bold action, ProMedica Foundation has established the ProMedica Impact Fund, a nationwide philanthropic approach to improving the health and well-being of individuals by accelerating efforts around SDOH. ProMedica will encourage donations to the fund throughout the LPGA event.

name: ProMedica and Kumanu Partner to Develop and Launch New Social Determinants of Health Solution for Employers Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica and Kumanu Partner to Develop and Launch New Social Determinants of Health Solution for Employers Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica and Kumanu Partner to Develop and Launch New Social Determinants of Health Solution for Employers

Press Release
ProMedica and Kumanu Partner to Develop and Launch New Social Determinants of Health Solution for Employers

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 29, 2020 – ProMedica, a mission-based, not-for-profit integrated health care organization, and Kumanu, a leading purpose-centered well-being technology firm have partnered to launch an innovative well-being solution for employers that addresses critical risk factors often not sufficiently accounted for in most corporate well-being programs: the social determinants of health (SDOH).

Social determinants of health are the social, economic, and environmental factors that impact health risks and outcomes. They include factors such as food insecurity, financial strain, housing, behavioral health, transportation, violence risks, and childcare. While clinical care accounts for only 20 percent of health outcomes, SDOH and behavior taken together influence around 80 percent, according to the Institute for Clinical Systems Improvement.

"The unmet needs around Social Determinants of Health – especially now as we contend with COVID-19 – demand a strong response from health care organizations and employers alike," noted Randy Oostra, president and chief executive officer of ProMedica. "Our decade-long experience addressing these needs, including pilot work with employers, demonstrates that focusing efforts in this area pays real dividends for employers, plus, it's the right thing to do for people. And now – working with our colleagues at Kumanu – we can do so at scale. Kumanu's work in life purpose is a major new addition to our SDOH work, and it adds one more very important piece as we try to improve individuals' personal, social and economic factors."

The ProMedica Social Determinants of Health Institute has been a national leader in effectively addressing SDOH in clinical settings and communities for more than a decade. Kumanu is known for its technology that fuses the latest neuroscience research with behavior design and machine learning to amplify and activate purpose, increase resilience, change mindsets, and achieve enduring behavior change. Drawing on both organizations' exceptional strengths, the new employee-focused well-being solution enables employers to take a purposeful and targeted approach to addressing the social determinants of health to reduce risks and improve health for their employees and organizations.

Powered by Kumanu’s PurposeCloud™ platform, this new employer-customizable solution incorporates:

  • Advanced analytics and predictive modeling to project population needs and risks
  • An easy-to-deploy confidential employee assessment tool
  • An app that uses purpose to amplify motivation while connecting people to health and human service resources
  • Consultative resources from The ProMedica Social Determinants of Health Institute and Kumanu purpose experts to integrate with existing employer well-being programs and incorporate best practices
  • Reporting and analytic dashboards that provide an aggregated view of risk, needs, engagement trends, and projected outcomes

“We’re delighted to partner with ProMedica in producing a robust solution that helps unlock the power of purpose, uncover latent needs, and build durable connections that make a profound difference in the lives of people, and the organizations they work for,” added Vic Strecher, PhD, founder and chief executive officer of Kumanu.

The new SDOH Solution for Employers will be available from both ProMedica and Kumanu.

name: ProMedica Researchers Observe Encouraging Outcomes with Use of Allogeneic Stem Cells in COVID19 Patients Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Researchers Observe Encouraging Outcomes with Use of Allogeneic Stem Cells in COVID-19 Patients Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Researchers Observe Encouraging Outcomes with Use of Allogeneic Stem Cells in COVID-19 Patients

Press Release
ProMedica Researchers Observe Encouraging Outcomes with Use of Allogeneic Stem Cells in COVID-19 Patients

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 28, 2020 – ProMedica today announced the promising results of its new study that evaluated the use of stem cells in the treatment of adult COVID-19 patients.

Eight patients elected to participate in a study under Emergency Investigational New Drug (IND) approval by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Patients received either one or two doses of allogeneic bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells manufactured by Stemedica Cell Technologies at its Current Good Manufacturing Practice (cGMP) compliant California State-licensed facility. The first set of patients was treated with one dose of 100 million cells, and the second set received two doses of 50 million cells.

The stem cell treatment resulted in an improved clinical course for the patients. Within 24-48 hours of receiving the stem cells, all patients had a significant reduction in oxygen requirements. Several patients went from an inability to talk or eat due to shortness of breath to speaking in full sentences and eating full meals comfortably shortly after treatment.

The study also found improved inflammatory modulation. In fact, 88 percent of patients had a significant reduction in acute phase reactants, which are markers for reductions in inflammation. The subsequent reduction in inflammatory markers resulted in a reduced ‘cytokine storm’ in 88 percent of patients. Researchers noted that these patients experienced quicker extubation, less lung trauma and less oxygen toxicity.

The stem cell treatment also seemed to accelerate post-discharge recovery. At their one-month follow-up appointments, the patients who received stem cells improved at a faster rate than comparable patients not treated with stem cells. The stem cell treated patients were tolerating more activity, walking farther and not requiring home oxygen when evaluated at 30 days post discharge.

“It has been really exciting for ProMedica to conduct this innovative research, and we are very encouraged by the results. We’re eager to move into the next phase of the study because of the significant potential to help COVID-19 patients, in particular those who continue to experience lung damage after contracting the virus,” said Greg Kasper, vice president medical affairs, metro region, ProMedica. “The residual circulating stem cells end up residing in the lungs as a reservoir, which may lead to improved long-term lung health and a better quality of life post-COVID-19.”

ProMedica is working to secure funding to advance a Phase 2 study in conjunction with Stemedica, a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company focused on the development and commercialization of progenitor cell and protein therapeutics for underserved medical conditions.

“We know that the immune-modulating properties of stem cells are quite remarkable in that they block the cytokine storm. COVID-19 offers a new frontier for exploring the potential benefits of stem cell therapy and, in particular, a clinical reduction of inflammation. The early findings and clinical outcomes of the study with ProMedica are encouraging, and we are hopeful to move into the next phase soon. Together, we have an opportunity to speed up the discovery of new treatments and potentially minimize the devastation of this pandemic,” said Nikolai Tankovich, president and chief medical officer, Stemedica.

name: ProMedica Foundation Announces 2020 Philanthropy Awards Recipients Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Foundation Announces 2020 Philanthropy Awards Recipients Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Foundation Announces 2020 Philanthropy Awards Recipients

Press Release
ProMedica Foundation Announces 2020 Philanthropy Awards Recipients

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 20, 2020 – ProMedica is pleased to announce the ProMedica Foundations 2020 Philanthropy Awards recipients. The annual awards ceremony was scheduled for April but was cancelled due to COVID-19 mandates. In lieu of the in-person ceremony, videos were made to honor each award winner and record his or her acceptance speech.

ProMedica’s 2020 Philanthropist of the Year is awarded to Dan and Sharon Farrell.

The ProMedica Philanthropist of the Year Award is given to individuals or couples who set a standard of excellence in the health and well-being of our community. They have provided financial support to improve health care at a ProMedica Institution or within the community. The candidates have generously volunteered their time and have taken a leadership role to encourage and inspire others to help ProMedica achieve its Mission.

Dan and Sharon Farrell are proud supporters of ProMedica and made a transformational gift to build and sustain Kaitlyn’s Cottage in Defiance, Ohio. Kaitlyn’s Cottage is a country cottage getaway designed for individuals with intellectual and physical disabilities and their families. “Dan and I were so blessed to partner with ProMedica in order to get this dream accomplished. I can’t tell you how many people have been impacted by Kaitlyn’s Cottage,” said Sharon Farrell.

Watch their video: https://youtu.be/MWrf5RDupM8 

ProMedica’s 2020 Young Philanthropist of the Year is awarded to Willie Jackson.

The ProMedica Young Philanthropist of the Year Award is given by the ProMedica Foundation to a young professional (age 19-39) who shows exemplary support to achieve ProMedica’s Mission. This individual has made donation(s) to support efforts to improve health care at a ProMedica Institution or within the community. The candidate is an advocate for ProMedica who inspires others to get involved and has made an impact to improve health and well-being in the communities ProMedica serves.

Willie Jackson, a University of Toledo Rockets basketball player, raised significant funds for the ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children's Hospital, formerly ProMedica Toledo Children's Hospital. “I just want to know I made an impact,” he said. His coach, Tod Kowalazyk, said, “To spend the time he’s invested and be a Division 1 athlete has not been easy on him. He’s certainly someone when he finds a passion, he puts his heart and soul into it.”

Watch his video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ufV3Lsfp3B0

ProMedica’s 2020 Junior Philanthropist of the Year is awarded to Rose Hajjar.

The ProMedica Junior Philanthropist of the Year Award is given by the ProMedica Foundation to a student (age 5-18) who has selflessly raised funds and/or volunteered to help improve the health and well-being of others. This person inspired his or her community to be generous and made a positive impact on someone’s life.

Rose Hajjar, a pediatric patient who had a heart transplant, raised significant funds with her sisters and inspired many more. “I would describe her as amazing,” said her pediatrician, Robert Mills, MD.

“Helping other children and people in the hospital and ProMedica makes me feel really good because I know what it’s like to be in the hospital,” said Hajjar.

Watch her video: https://youtu.be/VuFHWBWzD8A

ProMedica’s 2020 Mission Partner of the Year is awarded to Hollywood Casino Toledo.

The ProMedica Mission Partner of the year is given by the ProMedica Foundation to a business partner that has provided financial support to improve health care at a ProMedica Institution or within the community. The company’s commitment evokes transformative change in our community and helps ProMedica achieve its Mission to improve health and well-being.

Hollywood Casino Toledo supports many ProMedica programs, the Boys & Girls Clubs of Toledo, food reclamation programs and many other community partners. “We want to do more, and all we can, for our community,” said Justin Carter, general manager, Hollywood Casino Toledo.

Watch the video: https://youtu.be/rtpZnuCRm_4

ProMedica’s 2020 Philanthropy Champions of the Year is awarded to Rami Ubaydi, Denise Curry and Dr. Brian Dolsey.

The ProMedica Philanthropy Champions of the year is given by the ProMedica Foundation to a physician and an employee/department that has shown exemplary service to a ProMedica patient and the community. The candidates are advocates for outstanding health care as demonstrated through the compassion, hope, and healing they provide to their patients and the community.

Rami Ubaydi, vice president and general manager of ProMedica Senior Care, championed major initiatives as HCR Manor Care transitioned to a nonprofit. “The reason I chose to support ProMedica Health System is because of the social determinants of health and ‘give where you live’ programs. These two programs were new to me joining the combined company. We’re so glad to do more work in the community,” he said.

Watch his video: https://youtu.be/UC_WnZRD1Sk

Denise Curry, vice president and general manager for ProMedica Senior Care skilled nursing, was instrumental in improving the patient care experience and finding solutions in the community. Family is very important to Denise and that extends to her work and volunteer families. She can be found with her sleeves rolled up working side by side with the front-line facility teams as well as charity organizations she supports. “I’m very passionate that we’re doing all we can as individuals for our communities.” She continued, “There is more to come with how we are going to integrate positively with our communities.”

Watch her video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7TooM_b4eXQ

Brian Dolsey, MD, ProMedica Physicians Cardiology, championed ProMedica’s barbershop health program which first piloted in 2017 and diligently works to engage African-American men, who have higher rates of several chronic illnesses and cancer risks. The barbers in the shops were trained in CPR and Automated External Defibrillator (AED) Machines were installed in the shops.

“I want to be a good role model for my two sons and show them what it takes to be out there in the community. It makes me feel proud,” he said.

Watch his video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rtlB4ab8Cco

ProMedica’s 2020 Volunteer of the Year is awarded to Meg Ressner.

The ProMedica Volunteer of the Year is given by the ProMedica Foundation to an individual or group whose unselfish and dedicated service has made a significant difference in the lives of our patients, families, and community. The candidate inspires others to help ProMedica achieve its Mission.

Meg Ressner is an active volunteer leader for ProMedica. Her extensive board involvement includes roles on the ProMedica Russell J. Ebeid Children’s Hospital and ProMedica Toledo Hospital Foundation and Operating Boards, and Toledo Regional Autism Network Board. “She is the definition of ‘you will do better in Toledo’,” said Dawn Buskey, president, ProMedica Metro Region Acute Care.

“The current time to be involved with ProMedica is moving and inspiring. I’ve never been more proud of how much they have done during this pandemic,” said Ressner.

Watch her video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p7zBVSE-uNY

ProMedica’s Ebeid Healthy Neighborhood Partner of the Year is awarded to St. Paul Community Center.

The ProMedica Ebeid Healthy Neighborhood Partner of the Year is given by the ProMedica Foundation to a partner agency that has joined with ProMedica to help create communities where all individuals reach their highest potential for health. These businesses or individuals are committed to reshaping the health care delivery model to focus on the root causes of poor health by increasing access to healthy food, delivering nutritional education and providing job training opportunities.

St. Paul's Community Center was established in 1975 to provide food, shelter, support services and job and housing referrals to the homeless, indigent and mentally ill in the Toledo area. In 2018, St. Paul’s in partnership with the Ebeid Neighborhood Promise (ENP) initiative committed to a renewed focus on providing support to homeless individuals specifically with mental health issues who are known to seek outside shelter in the UpTown neighborhood navigate the newly adopted Lucas County Housing First Model.

In just under 12 months, through the ENP partnership, St. Paul has assisted more than 20 individuals in creating sustainable treatment plans that include addressing housing stability, cash benefits, employment, substance use, physical health, mental health and community supports. More broadly, St. Paul’s provided more than 12,000 nights of shelter to those experiencing homelessness. They served more than 111,000 meals, focused on providing healthy nutritious meals—often utilizing produce and food from Market on the Green.

“This award is an important signal that what we do is important, legitimate and impactful,” said Joe Habib, president and chief executive director, St. Paul’s Community Center.

Watch the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-m3s_e3kfE

name: ProMedica Bixby Hospital Ranked A Overall in Patient Outcomes Commitment to Equity and Community Health Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Bixby Hospital Ranked A+ Overall in Patient Outcomes, Commitment to Equity and Community Health Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Bixby Hospital Ranked A+ Overall in Patient Outcomes, Commitment to Equity and Community Health

Press Release
ProMedica Bixby Hospital Ranked A+ Overall in Patient Outcomes, Commitment to Equity and Community Health

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 16, 2020 –– ProMedica announced today that ProMedica Bixby Hospital received an A+ overall score in the new Lown Institute Hospitals Index, which evaluates clinical care as well community impact in terms of health equity and inclusivity.

ProMedica Bixby Hospital is among the top 10 highest-ranking hospitals in Michigan. The ranking system compared the performance of over 3,200 hospitals across the country, measuring three categories:

The ranking system compared the performance of over 3,200 hospitals across the country, measuring three categories:

  • Civic leadership – reflects an assessment of pay equity, community benefit spending, and inclusivity to evaluate how strongly hospitals are engaged with improving community health and well-being.
  • Value of care - reflects how well a hospital avoids the use of low-value services, medical services that offer no clinical benefit to patients and may harm them.
  • Patient outcomes - reflects a hospital's performance as it relates to its patients' health and experience of care. This category is calculated from three components: clinical outcomes, patient safety, and patient satisfaction

According to the Lown Institute, its new index is the first hospital ranking to take into account how much hospitals spend on community benefits, as well as the proportion of low-income patients they serve. It is also is the first hospital ranking to take into account how well hospitals serve people of lower income or education levels, and people of color. For more details about the Lown Institute Hospitals Index, visit https://lownhospitalsindex.org.

“At a time when communities are relying on them like never before, hospitals must rethink what it means to be great,” said Vikas Saini, M.D., president of the Lown Institute. “COVID-19 highlights how hospitals are essential community partners for anyone in need. To be great, however, a hospital cannot only provide care that’s high in quality. It must also deliver value and advance equality. Our index is designed to help them do just that.”

“We are proud of this special accolade,” said Julie Yaroch, D.O., president, ProMedica Bixby Hospital. “We are dedicated to maintaining exceptional levels of care and quality for each patient.”

The full list can be found here: https://lownhospitalsindex.org/rankings/.

.

name: Paramount Gives 10000 COVID19 Prevention Supply Kits to Ohioans in Need Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: Paramount Gives 10,000 COVID-19 Prevention Supply Kits to Ohioans in Need Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
Paramount Gives 10,000 COVID-19 Prevention Supply Kits to Ohioans in Need

Press Release
Paramount Gives 10,000 COVID-19 Prevention Supply Kits to Ohioans in Need

MAUMEE, Ohio, July 14, 2020 – Paramount today announced that the Paramount Advantage Medicaid is showing its support to Ohio communities by providing 10,000 COVID-19 prevention supply kits across the state.

 

The COVID-19 prevention supply kits were packed by approximately 50 Paramount employee volunteers on July 9 and 11. Each kit includes the following:

·         Disinfectant wipes

  • ·         Face masks
  • ·         Hand sanitizer
  • ·         Gloves

·         Soap

An information card is also provided that shares the importance and proper use of each item provided in the kits to minimize the risk of acquiring COVID-19.

Throughout the month of July, the supply kits will be mailed to community organizations, as well as Paramount Advantage Medicaid members who are at the highest risk. Each of the 53 Ohio Federally Qualified Health Center (FQHC’s) will receive 50 kits to give to patients -- not limited to Paramount insurance members.

 

“Our new normal may be anything but ordinary. However, we want to do our part to help people stay healthy,” said Lori Johnston, president, Paramount Health Care.

 

For more information about Paramount Health Care, visit www.paramounthealthcare.com.

name: The Kramer Heflinger Pediatric Endowment Fund Donates Two Medical Cribs to ProMedica Memorial Hospital
Title: The Kramer Heflinger Pediatric Endowment Fund Donates Two Medical Cribs to ProMedica Memorial Hospital
Description:
The Kramer Heflinger Pediatric Endowment Fund Donates Two Medical Cribs to ProMedica Memorial Hospital

Press Release
The Kramer Heflinger Pediatric Endowment Fund Donates Two Medical Cribs to ProMedica Memorial Hospital

FREMONT, Ohio, July 7, 2020 – The Kramer Heflinger Pediatric Endowment Fund, through the ProMedica Memorial Hospital Foundation, recently donated two medical cribs to ProMedica Memorial Hospital. The new cribs replaced older, outdated models. “We are so thankful to have such a supportive fund that allows us to improve the care we provide our youngest patients,” said Jodi Rucker, vice president of patient care services and chief nursing officer.

The Lindsey Kramer and Chad Heflinger Pediatric Endowment was established to help children who come to ProMedica Memorial Hospital and have expenses beyond their families’ means. This fund is available to children who are ill, 18 years old or younger, and who have lived in Sandusky County for at least a year. Parents who have a child younger than one year must have lived in Sandusky County for at least a year. The funds can be used to pay for ProMedica health care or co-pay expenses, transportation assistance, medication, or medical equipment and/or supplies.

For more information about the endowment fund or ProMedica Memorial Hospital Foundation, visit www.promedica.org/givefremont.

name: ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation Announces Cancer Patient Support Fund Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation Announces Cancer Patient Support Fund Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation Announces Cancer Patient Support Fund

Press Release
ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation Announces Cancer Patient Support Fund

FOSTORIA, Ohio, July 1, 2020 – ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation today announced its launch of the Jeff Shiff Run the Res Cancer Patient Support Fund to assist patients with the direct and indirect costs associated with cancer care. The fund helps patients who find themselves in emergent financial need while they are receiving cancer care at the ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Cancer Center. Patient needs may include, but are not limited to, health supplies, medications, health equipment, rent, utilities, car payment, car insurance, dental care, and transportation to and from appointments.

The Jeff Shiff Run the Res Cancer Patient Support Fund is made possible by charitable contributions to the ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation. The fund is named after its significant contributor: the ‘Run the Res.’

For many years, Susie Shiff, along with her family, have hosted the annual Run the Res Jeff Shiff 5k and 10k Run/Walk and the Kids Fun Run, in memory of her husband, Jeff, who lost his battle to colon cancer in 2008. “The year after my husband passed away, my four children and I went to Athens, Ohio to do a half marathon. After that race, we wanted to keep his memory alive by creating a race in Fostoria around the reservoir we all love,” said Susie Shiff. The event has raised more than $50,000 for patients and families at the Fostoria Community Hospital Cancer and Infusion Center.

The 2020 race is rescheduled for April 18th, 2021. A portion of the proceeds will be donated to the Jeff Shiff Run the Res Cancer Patient Support Fund. To register or for more information, call Susie Shiff at 419-435-1772.

“It is difficult enough to cope with a diagnosis of cancer without the added burden of financial stress that can occur as a result,” said Kim Partin at ProMedica Fostoria Community Hospital Foundation. “We’re pleased to be able to partner with our community to provide cancer patients with much needed support.”

For questions about the Jeff Shiff Run the Res Cancer Patient Support Fund, please call the Fostoria Community Hospital Cancer Center at 419-436-6626.

name: ProMedicas Jobst Vascular Institute Expands to Port Clinton Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica's Jobst Vascular Institute Expands to Port Clinton Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica's Jobst Vascular Institute Expands to Port Clinton

Press Release
ProMedicaâ€™s Jobst Vascular Institute Expands to Port Clinton

PORT CLINTON, Ohio, June 24, 2020 – ProMedica Physicians Jobst Vascular has opened a new clinic located at Magruder Hospital, 615 Fulton Street, Ste. 300, Port Clinton, Ohio, 43452.

The clinic will connect patients to the vascular care they need – whether it’s testing at a vascular lab, medical or surgical management of vascular disease, care for hard-to-heal wounds, or treatment for varicose or spider veins. Outpatient surgeries will be available including AV fistula creation, wound debridement and varicose vein procedures.

The clinic will be open on Wednesdays from 8:30 a.m. – noon and will be staffed by Gregory Walker, DO, and Brett Aplin, MD, ProMedica Physicians Jobst Vascular.

ProMedica is a mission-based, not-for-profit integrated healthcare organization headquartered in Toledo, Ohio. It serves communities in 27 states. The organization offers acute and ambulatory care, an insurance company with a dental plan, and post-acute and academic business lines. The organization has more than 56,000 employees, 13 hospitals, 2,100+ physicians and advanced practice providers with privileges, 900+ healthcare providers employed by ProMedica Physicians, a health plan, and 335 assisted living facilities, skilled nursing and rehabilitation centers, memory care communities, outpatient rehabilitation clinics, and hospice and home health care agencies. Driven by its mission to improve your health and well-being, ProMedica has been nationally recognized for its advocacy programs and efforts to address social determinants of health. For more information about ProMedica, please visit www.promedica.org/aboutus.

name: ProMedica Shares Proposal Highlights Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Shares Proposal Highlights Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Shares Proposal Highlights

Press Release
ProMedica Shares Proposal Highlights

While there has been a lot of talk about UTMC in the media, ProMedica has been busy listening — listening to the publicly shared concerns of the University of Toledo (UToledo), UTMC employees, and the community.

ProMedica believes it offers a unique local solution that would meet the needs of all of the major constituents and preserve UTMC as a publicly-owned hospital by UToledo. Therefore, we have decided to respond to UToledo’s request for proposal. Our proposal presents a model for the joint operation of UTMC by UToledo and ProMedica that would enable UTMC to become financially sustainable. Under the model, UToledo would maintain ownership and ultimate control of UTMC, and ProMedica would provide management and other services.

Though publicly sharing our intentions this early in the process is not standard, we felt it was important to do so to ensure maximum openness and transparency. ProMedica proposes to:

  • Maintain UTMC as a vital asset for the community – by continuing to provide healthcare services including primary care, emergency care, cardiology, neurology, and orthopaedics on the campus of UTMC.
  • Quickly stabilize UToledo’s financial concerns related to UTMC – by utilizing ProMedica’s local healthcare management expertise and resources.
  • Address desperately needed care identified in our community health assessment – by growing the hospital with investments in service lines, including primary, behavioral health, and psychiatric care.
  • Retain high-quality State of Ohio jobs in our community – by UToledo employees remaining state employees with the benefits that go along with that designation, including state health care, state retirement plans, tuition reimbursement, seniority and others.
  • Replace UTMC’s obsolete electronic medical record (EMR) system – by utilizing ProMedica’s existing relationships and experience in designing and implementing industry-leading, cost-effective EMR solutions that meet regulatory standards.
  • Support the UToledo College of Medicine mission – by continuing to offer academic and research opportunities at UTMC.
  • Preserve UToledo’s oversight of UTMC – by using a joint operating model that ensures UToledo will maintain ultimate control of UTMC and continue making important decisions that impact the health and well-being of South Toledo.

    • A neutral third-party advisor is expected to review proposal submissions and make recommendations to the University of Toledo Board of Trustees. We appreciate the opportunity to put forth a forward-thinking solution that we sincerely believe will offer the greatest benefit to our community.

name: ProMedica Eases Michigan Hospital Visitor Restrictions for Adult Patients Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Eases Michigan Hospital Visitor Restrictions for Adult Patients Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Eases Michigan Hospital Visitor Restrictions for Adult Patients

Press Release
ProMedica Eases Michigan Hospital Visitor Restrictions for Adult Patients

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 9, 2020 – ProMedica announced today that it has eased some of its Michigan-based hospital visitor restrictions for adult patients that had been in place since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic in its service area. The change is in accordance with guidance from the Michigan governor’s office and the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services.

The health system has a three-tiered hospital visitor restriction policy in the event of a pandemic. Since March, it had been implementing a level 3 visitor restriction, which is its strictest level. Effective immediately, ProMedica hospitals and outpatient surgery facilities in Michigan will shift to a level 2 visitor restriction.

ProMedica Level 2 Visitor Restrictions Highlights:

For adult patients who are not COVID-19 suspect or confirmed, the following visitor guidelines apply:

  • One designated visitor over the age of 18 will be permitted for the duration of the hospital stay.
  • Visitors will be screened upon arrival for symptoms of acute respiratory illness, and those with symptoms will not be permitted to enter the facility.
  • A visitor under the age of 18 may be allowed if he/she is the parent of a minor child.

All visitors who meet the above criteria must:

  • Wear a mask at all times
  • Practice appropriate cough etiquette
  • Maintain appropriate social distancing

For adult patients who are COVID-19 suspect or confirmed, no visitors are permitted inside of the patients’ rooms. However, alternative mechanisms for patient and visitor interactions, such as video-call applications on cell phones or tablets, are offered. Exceptions for extenuating circumstances are possible and would be determined on a case-by-case basis.

ProMedica will continue to monitor the evolving COVID-19 pandemic closely and make any appropriate adjustments to visitor restrictions to comply with state requirements or ordinances and to help ensure the safety of all in its facilities.

For more details about ProMedica’s current visitor restrictions, including those for specialty areas, click here.

name: We Stand with Communities Across the Nation
Title: We Stand with Communities Across the Nation
Description:
We Stand with Communities Across the Nation

Press Release
We Stand with Communities Across the Nation

This weekend’s protests stirred something deep within all of us at ProMedica. Our expectation is for our communities to be safe for everyone, no matter their color. The violence and criminal acts against George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor and countless other victims of racism are unacceptable. We join others who are raising their voice to speak out against the systemic injustice to people of color. We stand with the communities across the nation that are working to solve racial issues.

ProMedica’s mission is to improve the health and well-being of the communities we live and work in across this country. While we have come to ProMedica from many different backgrounds and roles, what brings us together is our calling to serve those who need our care when they are the most vulnerable. We provide this care within our walls and within our communities, including our decade-long commitment to address social determinants of health. We know our organization and our communities are stronger, smarter and better when they are diverse and inclusive. We will not sit idly by, but work with others to eliminate racism, hatred and discrimination. We urge you to join us.

name: ProMedica Bay Park Hospital Safely Resumes Normal Operations after Height of COVID19 Toledo Ohio OH ProMedica Health System
Title: ProMedica Bay Park Hospital Safely Resumes Normal Operations after Height of COVID-19 Toledo, Ohio (OH), ProMedica Health System
Description:
ProMedica Bay Park Hospital Safely Resumes Normal Operations after Height of COVID-19

Press Release
ProMedica Bay Park Hospital Safely Resumes Normal Operations after Height of COVID-19

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 2, 2020 – ProMedica is pleased to announce that ProMedica Bay Park Hospital has safely transitioned to normal operations as a strong, comprehensive community hospital after serving as the system’s primary facility for COVID-19 patients March through May.

“Bay Park Hospital staff did an amazing job caring for our sickest patients during the earlier stages of the pandemic when there was still much uncertainty,” said Dawn Buskey, president, ProMedica Metro Region Acute Care. Over the past couple of months, our system has learned a great deal about treating COVID-19, and we are well-prepared to do so safely in specially designated areas at all of our hospitals. That’s why we decided that it was time to transition Bay Park Hospital back to normal operations.”

The first step in transitioning Bay Park Hospital to normal operations was to routinely treat and admit COVID-19 positive and suspected positive adult patients at their local ProMedica hospitals starting on May 14. Soon after, Bay Park Hospital began accepting non-COVID-19 admissions.

“We have taken a systematic, phased-in approach to resuming normal hospital operations,” said Dr. Ravi Narra, vice president of medical affairs at ProMedica Bay Park Hospital. “Just as we strategically designated Bay Park Hospital as the centralized COVID-19 facility, we have been very thoughtful about returning to normal operations.”

The next step was to re-open surgery services at Bay Park Hospital. Consistent with state guidelines, Bay Park is performing all essential surgeries and non-essential surgeries that do not require an overnight stay. Ambulatory diagnostic testing capabilities at Bay Park Hospital resumed on May 18. These include non-time sensitive fluoroscopy, mammograms, ultrasound, DEXA, and lung cancer screenings.

ProMedica Physicians’ offices in the Bay Park Medical Office Building that were impacted by the hospital’s COVID-19 designation began re-opening for in-person visits over the past few weeks. This week, the final offices, including ProMedica Physicians Obstetrics and Gynecology – Oregon and ProMedica Physicians Cardiology – Oregon re-opened.

“Thank you to everyone who has supported our staff and patients during this challenging time,” said Buskey. While the pandemic is not over, we are hopeful about our path forward as a health system and as a community. With the lessons learned and a strengthened sense of purpose, our staff at all of our hospitals stand ready to deliver safe, compassionate, quality care for all severe injuries and illnesses.”
